quote: What if I say something dumb?   Something that makes him   uncomfortable?
Like what?
Like... "How's your new leg?"
I think he's probably expecting a   few questions.
I just don't want to say the   wrong thing.
You'll be fine. But maybe I   shouldn't be there when he   arrives.
Why?

Well... when he was in the   hospital, he didn't answer any of   my letters -- that's okay. I   mean, I'm only his stepmother.   He's going through something so   personal... maybe he only wants   his real family around.
You are real family.

That's right. And you should   both just relax. Yes, Nog has   lost a leg and that's a traumatic   experience. But you're not going   to say or do anything that'll be   worse than what he's already gone   through. Just be happy to see   him and tell him you love him.   For today, that'll be enough.
They've docked.
You sure this is the right   transport, colonel?
I checked the passenger list this   morning. He definitely boarded   at --
Nog!
Welcome home! We love you! You   look great! It's so good to have   you back! Welcome back! The   station wasn't the same without   you! Etc.
Uh... thank you. It's good to be   back.       My orders, captain.
Medical leave? How can that be?
Sounds like an excuse to loaf   around while the rest of us are   working.
Work and lots of it, that's my   prescription.
The Defiant plasma conduits could   use an overhaul.
My drink replicator could use   some work.
Captain, maybe he forged those   orders.
I'm afraid they're genuine.   Ensign Nog has no duties until   further notice. Except... to   attend a welcome home party in   the wardroom!
If it's all the same to you,   sir... I'm pretty tired. I'd   rather just... go to my quarters.   Is that all right?
Absolutely. We'll celebrate   after you've settled in.
Great.
I can carry that.
I've got it.
Well. If you'll excuse me...
Did I do something wrong?
... and Julian and Miles have   become even more obsessed with   their Alamo program if you can   believe it. I half expect Miles   to start wearing a coonskin cap   to work.
You see... Davy Crockett wore   this cap made of... a raccoonskin   and...
I know the program.
Oh.       Well, I think we've covered just   about everything you missed while   you were away.
Is there anything you want to   talk about?
Not particularly.
Here it comes...
What?

The "cane problem." You're about   to ask me why I need to walk with   the cane since Doctor Benbasset   told you my biosynthetic leg is   working perfectly. He also told   you the problem's all in my head.   That I'm crazy.
He didn't say that.
It's what he thinks.
Forget what he thinks. What do   you think? Why do you need the   cane?
My leg hurts. And if I put my   full weight on it, it hurts more.   So I have to limp. And that   means I need to walk with a cane.
Sounds reasonable to me.

Good.       Look -- can I be perfectly honest   with you?       I've spent the last three weeks   talking about my feelings with   the counselors on Starbase Two-   Three-Five... and to tell you the   truth, I'm a little sick of it.   I just want to be left alone for   a while.
I understand. I think we've done   enough for today.       I'll see you tomorrow.
Computer -- what time is it?
The time is eleven thirty-two   hours.
Jake says he's sleeping over   eighteen hours a day and Julian   says he's missed his last two   physical therapy appointments.

And his counseling sessions are   going nowhere -- in his words,   he's "sick of talking about his   feelings." Can't say I blame   him. He's been under constant   psychiatric care for almost two   months now.
So what do we do?
I'm not sure. For now, our best   option may be to simply watch and   wait.
Not my first choice.
I know. But sometimes a patient   can help guide his own treatment.   Let's see what Nog does next.
Nog, I want to be understanding   and I want to be your friend, but   enough is enough. You've been   playing that same stupid song for   three days. I can't take it   anymore.
Aren't you going to say anything?   You've barely said three words to   me since you came home.
Maybe I don't have anything to   say.
I'm trying to help you here, Nog,   but you're not making it easy.
You want to help me? Fine.   Leave me alone.
All right. But if you want to   hear that song again, go rent a   holosuite.
... so in order to salvage the   femoral motor nerves... I'm   afraid I have to amputate your   leg just above the knee. I'm   sorry, but there's no other   choice.
Program is running. You may   enter when ready.
Hi there, pallie. Vic Fontaine.
I know. I'm Nog.
You're Rom's kid, right?
Right.
He's really proud of you -- he's   always in here bragging about his   son, the soldier boy.
Yeah.
What can I do for you?
I want to hear, "I'll Be Seeing   You."
Sure thing, kiddo. Any other   requests?
No. Just "I'll Be Seeing You."
Sounds like it's a special tune.
It is. It helped me out once   when I was... unhappy.
What more can you ask from a   song?
Doctor?
Yes?
What is that?
It's a song I had Vic Fontaine   record for me.
Vic... ?
He's a character in a holosuite   program of mine. I thought it   might take our minds off our   troubles.       Is it bothering you?
No. It's kind of nice...
Thank you.       Take five, fellas.
That's it, kid. I know fifteen   different arrangements of that   tune and you've heard 'em all.   So, which one's your favorite?
The first.
Somehow, I knew you were going to   say that.
So let me guess -- Julian played   it for you, right?
Right.
If I had him as a publicist I'd   be bigger than Elvis.
Who?
Never mind.       So how's the new leg?
You know about that?
People talk.
If you really want to know...   it hurts.
Can they give you something for   that?

No, they say it's all in my head.   "According to my tricorder, the   pain receptors in your leg aren't   being stimulated, Nog. You must   be imagining it." But I don't   care what they say, it hurts all   the time.
I believe you.
You're the only one.
So what else can I do for you?   Sing it again?
Good. To tell you the truth, I   was starting to get a little sick   of it myself. How 'bout   something else?
No... all I want to do is go to   bed.
Okay. I'll catch you later.
Yeah.
Something wrong?
I don't want to go back to my   quarters...       Actually, I don't want to go back   to my life...
Where do you live -- in this   program, I mean. Do you have   a... house or... ?
I have a suite here in the hotel.
Do you have an extra room?
Sure.       You want to stay with me tonight?
Maybe more than just tonight.       Officially, I'm on medical leave,   and according to regulations I   can choose my own rehabilitation   facility.
You want to choose a holosuite   program for your rehab?
Why not?
Okay, kid. If that's the way you   want it. From now on, you're   staying with me.
Great.
Crazy.
My son is insane.
Rom...
He's a one-legged crazy man!
He's not crazy.
But he is living in a holosuite.
At first, it struck me as a   little... peculiar. But after I   thought it over, I began to think   that maybe this is a good sign   after all.
How can hiding in one of Julian's   adolescent programs be a good sign?
Hey...
It could be worse. He could be   hiding in the Alamo program.
Or that ridiculous secret agent   program.
Hey.
Or that stupid Viking program.
Hey!
All right.       Are you sure this is in Nog's   best interest?
No, I'm not sure. But I think   Nog might be subconsciously   seeking out his own form of   therapy.
I'm sorry, but moving into a   holosuite is not my idea of   therapy.
Okay, it sounds a little odd.
It sounds ridiculous.
Not really. I'm with Ezri on   this one. The mind has a strong   natural instinct for survival.   For whatever reason, Nog's mind   has found shelter in the world of   Vic Fontaine.
I think we should wait and let   this play itself out.
Well, then someone should talk   with Vic -- make him aware of   Nog's emotional and physical   condition.
I'll do it.
And who's going to pay for all   this holosuite time?
I guess I am.
And it's very generous of you.    (stands, then to    Ezri)   Keep me informed.
I get it. He's got some healing   to do. I could see that the   moment he walked in here.
Great. Any questions?
You sure he doesn't need the   cane? Because he's pretty sure   he does.
I'm positive. It's a   psychological need, not a   physical one.
Well, in that case, I've got some   ideas on how to wean him off the   stick.
Okay, but don't push it.
Hey -- do I seem pushy to you?
No.       Well, you know where to reach me   if you have any problems.
I got your number.
Hey, kid.
Hey, Vic.       Have you seen this movie?
Oh, yeah.
I've heard about you.
What have you heard, Shane?
I've heard that you're a low down   Yankee liar.
From these books I can't tell if   I'm rich as Rockefeller or poor   as a churchmouse.
It's not real money, Vic. Don't   worry about it.
Hey, it's real to me, kid.
I could have the computer put   some money in your account.
No, thanks. I'll figure it out.
I gotta be going on.
Why, Shane?
Didn't he just get shot a minute   ago?
Yeah. He took one in the arm.
But he's not bleeding. He's not   even in pain!
Noggles, take it easy -- it's   only a movie.
Shane! Come back!
I liked The Searchers better.
Who doesn't?       Sonuvagun! I gotta get ready for   the show.
The show? I thought we were   hanging in.
Hanging out. And we are, but I   have a gig to do.
Cancel it.
I can't do that.
Why not?
It would be unprofessional.   Besides, performing is my life.   It's what I do. I gotta get out   there and swing or I'm just   another clyde in a tux.       You coming to the show?
Sure.
Then may I suggest you carry   something with a little more   style...
Now this is a cane.
It's a replica of the one Errol   Flynn used to have. Except his   was a little taller.
It's beautiful... reminds me of   the Grand Nagus's staff.
And it has a little secret --   press that button on the back of   the head.
It's great. But what's it for?
You never know when a lady might   need a light. Now be careful   with that stick, it's a little   fragile -- I don't think it'll   take your whole weight.
Actually, I don't need to put my   whole weight on it.
Good. Now we better get dressed.
Tuxedoes?
Hey -- you're catching on.
Hi there.
Nog, let me introduce you to --
Down in front!
Sorry.
Nog, this is Kesha. Kesha --   Nog.
Nice to meet you.
Welcome to Las Vegas.
Thanks.
Thank you, you're too kind. I   guess that's the response you get   when you pack the house with   relatives.
So what've you been doing?
Hanging out.
Out of what?
It's an expression.
There's a lot of old Earth slang   in this program.       Right, Daddy-O?
Right.
Why don't I get us some drinks?   Kesha, what'll you have?
Makara fizz.
They don't serve that here.
Oh. Well, what're you having?
A martini. Two olives.
I'll have the same.
Be right back.
Jake says you're going to be the   first Ferengi captain in   Starfleet.
We'll see.
He also says you're quite a hero.
I'm not a hero.
Don't be so modest. Jake's not   the only one. Everyone on the   station says that --
I said, I'm not a hero. Okay?
Okay.
Which one?
What?
That's what you're wondering   right? Which leg is it?
I -- I wasn't wondering about...   that...
About what?
About your... you know...
My new leg? Can't you say it?
No -- yes. I mean, I'm not   trying to say anything...
Then maybe you should just keep   quiet.
Here we go -- three martinis.
I think we should go, Jake.
That sounds like a good idea.
Uh... what's going on?
It's all my fault. I didn't mean   to stare...
At what?
What do you think?
Oh...
I'm really sorry if I made you   uncomfortable.
Wonderful. Good-bye.
Hold on. She said she was sorry.
I heard her. Now you can go.
What's wrong with you?
I said get out.
Nog...
Let me put it another way...
You okay?
Yeah... I'm fine.
And you... take a hike.
What?
You heard me. You don't come   into my club and start hitting   customers. Now get out before I   throw you out.
Still up?
I couldn't sleep.
You mind... ?
What a night...
I'm sorry about what happened.
Don't apologize to me -- I'm not   the one you belted.
I'll settle things with Jake.
And his girl.
Absolutely.       Can I go back to the club   tomorrow night?
I can't have you hitting the   customers. It's bad for   business.
I promise it'll never happen   again.
Okay. What got into you, anyway?
I don't know. She started   calling me a hero and things kind   of went downhill from there.
She called you a hero? And for   that you slug your best friend?   Remind me not to pay you any   compliments.
I am beat.       That's never happened before.
What?
Me getting tired. My program's   never run this long. Usually   people come in, they ask for a   song or two... sometimes a night   on the town... but I've never had   to put in a full day.
Maybe you should go to bed.
I got work to do. If I don't get   those books in order, Uncle Sam   is going to come down on me like   a ton of bricks.
Sounds like my uncle. Is there   anything I can do?
You know anything about   bookkeeping?
I'm a Ferengi. It's in our   blood.
They're all yours.
Where's your computer?
Right here.       It's nineteen sixty-two. What do   you want from me?
It's all right. I can do it this   way.
Well, I'm going to hit the sack.
Vic, can I ask you a question?
Sure.
When you sleep... do you dream?
Good-night, kid.
Good-night.

... but this time he's switched   all the robes in the steam room.   So when Dino goes to pick up his   robe, he doesn't realize that   across the back, Frank has   written, in big bold letters--    (catches sight of    Ezri)   I'll finish the story later.
Hi, dollface.
Hi. Where's Nog?
Up in the room. He's still   working on the receipts from   sixty-one. That's kid's a hell   of an accountant. He says the   government owes me money -- can   you believe that?
I need to talk to him.
Can it wait?
I'm afraid not.
This is about the thing with   Jake, right? Is he pressing   charges?
No. But I think it's time for   Nog to leave the holosuite.
Wait a minute. He likes it here.   He's making real progress. Okay,   he lost his cool, but I don't   think it'll happen again.
Vic, he can't hide in here   forever. He has to face reality   sometime.
The kid's had too much reality   lately, if you ask me. He's lost   a leg, he's watched good friends   die. Like you told me, we   shouldn't push him -- he needs   time to heal.
No offense, but you're just a   hologram. I'm his counselor. I   outrank you... or something. And   I think it's time for him to go.
He's on medical leave. And   according to Starfleet   regulations, he can spend it   anywhere he chooses.
How do you know that?
I told him.
And if you try to force me to   leave I'll resign my commission.
Wait a minute... let's slow down   here. No one's talking about   forcing anyone to do anything.
Good. Because Vic and I have big   plans.
We do?
I've been going over your books.   This place is a latinum-mine and   you don't even know it. In my   opinion, it's time to expand the   business.
Nog, this is a holosuite.
Of course it's a holosuite. But   that doesn't mean we can't build   a new casino.
A new casino?    (takes the adding    machine tape)   How much money do I have?
If you'll excuse us, counselor, we   have business to conduct...
Go easy on the garnishes. People   order a drink, they don't want a   fruit bowl in their glass.
We'll talk about this later.
I'll take care of them.
Hey -- long time, no see.
Hi.
Oh, Nog!
Right this way...
So... how are you?
Couldn't be better. Business is   booming. We're making money hand   over fist. I can barely keep up   with all the profits.
Those are... holographic profits,   right?
Uh... yeah.       So what's new with you?
Rom got a promotion.
Maintenance engineer first class.
That's great! Congratulations!
Thanks.
We should celebrate. We could   close the lounge, have a private   party...
Actually, Chief O'Brien threw him   a party last night.
Oh.
It was a spur of the moment   thing... no invitations or   anything...
Don't worry about it. I probably   couldn't have gotten away -- last   night was really busy...
Uh-oh. A big player just walked   in. Excuse me for a minute -- I   have to go schmooze.
Okay. See you later.
'Bye.
I hope you're still talking to   me...
Of course I am.
I've got to hand it to you, Vic,   you've done a great job with him.   He seems like a new man.
He just needed a little time,   that's all.
... heals all wounds, right?
Giving him that cane was a great   idea. I haven't seen him limp in   days.
It gets better. Yesterday, we   drove out to see the architect   who's designing the casino, and I   saw him actually run up a flight   of stairs.
No kidding.
Would I kid a kidder?
So what's next for you two?

Well, we don't break ground on   the casino for another week, so I   thought we could fly up to Tahoe   for a couple of days. Sammy's   going to be performing at the Cal-   Neva and I thought I'd introduce   the kid to him.
Sammy's a friend of yours... ?
We're tight.
I see. So you're going to have   Sammy convince him it's time to   leave the holosuite?
Well... no.

Forget it. I should know better   by now than to ask you to give   away your secrets. You probably   have everything all mapped out.       I mean, what am I thinking? That   this "new casino" is anything   more than a ploy? That you're   really going to let him live out   the rest of his life in a   holosuite?
No... no, of course not. The   casino's just a... a ploy, like   you said.
They'll be so happy to have him   back.
Yeah...
He is better, isn't he?
It's just like you said -- he   needed a break from reality. Now   all that's left is to decide when   he's ready to go back. But I'll   leave that up to you.       See you 'round.
See ya.
Great set tonight.
Thanks.       Lot of familiar faces in the   crowd. Did I see Rom and Leeta   out there?
They came for a while.
What do you think about moving   the crap tables over to the south   wing and expanding the slot   machines out into here?
Good idea.
I'll think it over.
But I'm supposed to meet with the   architect tomorrow morning.
Not anymore.       It's time for you to go, kid.
Go where?
You know where. It's time to end   the program.
But... we've got work to do... we   have a casino to build.
No we don't. This is just a   fantasy... it's not real.
It's real to me and it's real to   you -- and don't say it isn't. I   know better.
You're right -- it's very real to   me. But I'm a hologram, Nog.   I'm not a person. Until you came   along, I'd never been on for more   than six or seven hours straight.
I know! But now you're running   all the time. Isn't it great?

It's incredible. Since you've   been here, I've slept in a bed   every night... gone to work every   day... had time to read the   paper, play cards with the boys   I've had a life. And I have to   tell you, it's a precious thing   I had no idea how much it means   to just... live.       Now, I'm going to return the   favor and give you your life   back.
But I don't want that life   anymore, Vic. I'm perfectly   happy here.
What "here?" There is no "here."   Don't you get it? This is   nowhere. It's an illusion. And   so am I. In fact, the only thing   in this entire program that isn't   an illusion is you.
Okay. You're right. But I'm not   ready to go back yet. I need   more time. So let's just sleep   on this and we'll talk about it   tomorrow.
Kid... I hate to do this to you,   but you're not giving me any   choice. Computer --
No, don't!
-- end program.
Oh. Hi, Nog.
Chief. Something wrong?
Uh... no. I was running a   diagnostic in Ops and noticed a   magnetic flux anomaly in the   holosuite transilluminator   circuits. Didn't realize it was   you.
Sorry. I'm... just having   trouble getting the Las Vegas   program to run.
You know... Vic's matrix is a   little different than your   standard photokinetic hologram.   He can turn himself off. If he   doesn't want to appear... he   doesn't.
You mean he has free will?
I'm an engineer, not a philosopher.   All I know is that when Vic turns   himself off, he's off, and ripping   out the guts of the holosuite isn't   going to change that.
Is there anything else I can do   for you?
No.
We uh... we all miss you in Ops.
Yeah.
... now that the chief's told you   I'm smarter than the average   bear, will you stop messin'   around with my holosuite?
If you'll turn the program back on.
What is it I'm not making clear   to you, Charley? You have to go.
You don't get it. I... I can't   go out there.
Why not?
I'm... scared. Okay? I'm   scared.

When the war started, I wasn't...   happy or anything, but I was...   eager. I wanted to test   myself... I wanted to see if I   had what it takes to be a   soldier. And I saw a lot of   combat... I saw a lot of people   get hurt... I saw a lot of people   die... but I never thought   anything was going to happen to   me. Then suddenly Doctor Bashir   is telling me he has to cut my   leg off.       I couldn't believe it. I still   can't believe it.       If I can get shot... if I can   lose a leg... anything could   happen to me, Vic. I could die   tomorrow. I don't know if I can   face that. If I stay here, at   least I know what the future's   going to be like.
You stay in here, you're going to   die. Not all at once, but little   by little. Eventually, you'll   become as hollow as I am.
You don't seem hollow to me.
Compared to you, I'm hollow as a   snare drum.

Kid, I don't know what's going to   happen to you out there. All I   can tell you is that you've got   to play the cards life deals you.   Sometimes you win, sometimes you   lose... but at least you're in   the game.
Crazy.
He seemed happy...
And he's stopped limping...
You're joking.
No. He's a new man. You should   go visit.
I don't think I need to...
Hi.
Hi.
Are you okay?
No.       But I will be.
Computer -- run program Bashir   sixty-two.
Hi, pallie. Nice threads.
Thanks.
You back at work?
Limited duty. Just a couple   hours a day.
How's it feel?
Different. I feel... older.
Happens to the best of us.
I wanted to thank you for all you   did for me.
That's not necessary. You did   something for me too -- you gave   me a chance to see what it's like   to have a life.
You're going to have that chance   again. I've made arrangements   with my uncle Quark to keep this   program running twenty-six hours   a day from now on.
What?
It's my gift to you.
Kid... I don't know what to say.
Just put it there, pallie and   tell me you'll always save me a   seat up front.
It's a deal. And you can take   that to the bank.
Gotta go. I'm buying Jake and   Kesha dinner tonight.
Try not to overturn the furniture.
I'll try...
Twenty-six hours a day...
"I've got the world on a   string/Sitting on a rainbow/Got   the string around my finger/What   a world, what a life... "
"I'm in love... "
